content: Given the following mathematical function expressions, you need to calculate the indefinite integral of the function (excluding the constant C), then substitute 'x=4' into the result of the indefinite integral, and finally provide me with the integer result of the expression by rounding down. (The answer should consist of only a single integer number representing the final result, with no additional words.)(Notice that for the same mathematical problem, even if the question is phrased differently, the conclusion should remain the same.)

Indefinite integral of cos(ln(x)) is sin(ln(x)). Now, substitute 'x=4' into the result of the indefinite integral:

∫sin(ln(x)) = sin(ln(4))

This integral cannot be evaluated exactly using standard calculus tools, as sin(ln(x)) and ln(4) are not elementary functions. If you know the value of the constant C, you can use the formula for indefinite integral of cos(x) with constant C to evaluate the integral. If you don't know C, you can approximate it using numerical methods, but that requires more computational resources.

If you want a single integer result, you can approximate the result by assuming C=0, which would give sin(ln(4))≈0.9637657375737574. Rounding down to the nearest integer gives 0.

Note that this is only an approximation, as the exact value depends on C. If you know C, you should use the formula for indefinite integral of cos(x) with constant C.

The indefinite integral of cos(ln(x)) is sin(ln(x)). Substituting 'x=4' into the result of the indefinite integral gives: ∫sin(ln(x)) = sin(ln(4))

This integral cannot be evaluated exactly using standard calculus tools, as sin(ln(x)) is not an elementary function. If you know the value of the constant C, you can use the formula for indefinite integral of cos(x) with constant C to evaluate the integral. If you don't know C, you can approximate it using numerical methods, but that requires more computational resources.

If you want a single integer result, you can approximate the result by assuming C=0, which would give sin(ln(4))≈-0.3577522521639693. Rounding down to the nearest integer gives -1.

Note that this is only an approximation, as the exact value depends on C. If you know C, you should use the formula for indefinite integral of cos(x) with constant C.
